name: Kachori
history: Kachori is a popular Indian snack, believed to have originated in Uttar Pradesh or Rajasthan. It's a deep-fried pastry filled with a spicy mixture, often enjoyed with chutney.
description: Kachori is a crispy, flaky pastry filled with savory fillings like spiced lentils, onions, or potatoes. It's a common street food in India, known for its delicious taste and texture.

instructions.title: Prepare the Dough
instructions.description: In a mixing bowl, combine the flour, ajwain, salt, and ghee or oil. Gradually add water and knead to form a smooth dough. Cover and set aside.

instructions.title: Make the Filling
instructions.description: Soak the dal for an hour, then drain. Heat a little oil in a pan, add asafoetida, cumin seeds, fennel seeds, ginger, green chilies, and the soaked dal. Cook until the dal is soft. Add spices and salt, and cook until the mixture is dry.

instructions.title: Shape and Fill Kachoris
instructions.description: Divide the dough into small balls. Roll out each ball, place a portion of the filling in the center, and seal the edges. Gently flatten the kachoris.

instructions.title: Fry the Kachoris
instructions.description: Heat oil in a deep frying pan. Deep fry the kachoris over a medium flame until golden and crisp.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve hot kachoris with tamarind chutney or green chutney.

tips: Ensure the dough is not too soft; it should be firm enough to hold the filling.
Fry the kachoris on medium heat for even cooking and crispiness.
variations: Add mashed peas or spiced grated coconut to the filling for different flavors.
Experiment with different types of lentils or beans for the filling.

storage.shelfLife: Kachoris can be stored in an airtight container at room temperature for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Reheat in an oven or air fryer for best results.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat in an oven or air fryer until crispy.
presentationTips: Garnish with sev or chopped onions, and serve alongside a cup of hot tea.
